- This partnership follows Uber's similar collaboration with OpenAI, highlighting the competitive nature of AI integration in ride-hailing services.
- Lyft's AI assistant uses Anthropic’s Claude, a large language model, to provide human-like responses and handle common support issues.
- Lyft's broader collaboration includes training and tools integration for its engineers to utilize AI in various processes.
- Lyft has partnered with Amazon and Anthropic to integrate AI into customer support using Anthropic’s Claude AI via Amazon Bedrock.

title: Google Adds Digital Watermarks for AI-Edited Images Using Magic Editor
summary:

- The Reimagine tool allows significant image modifications, raising concerns about distinguishing AI-altered content.
- Digital watermarking aims to enhance transparency in AI editing, helping users identify altered images.
- Google utilizes SynthID to embed watermarks without affecting original image quality; it also works with AI-generated text and video.
- Watermarks can be viewed in image metadata through 'About this Image' in Google Photos.
- This feature is specifically available for Pixel 9 devices and was released in the week of February 6, 2025.
- SynthID, developed by Google's DeepMind division, allows for watermark verification as well.
- Currently, the technology supports beta testing for various AI-generated content formats.

title: Google to compensate Israeli users in Play Store settlement
summary:
- Google has begun compensating Israeli consumers as part of a class action settlement regarding its Play Store subscription policies.
- Total compensation amounts to 46.5 million shekels (approximately US$13.1 million).
- The lawsuit, initiated in 2017 by Mordechai Malachi, alleged that Google misled users about its auto-renewing subscription policies.
- Users will receive 55% refunds of their subscription fees, and those who canceled early will get a one-time 25% compensation.
- The Central District Court in Lod approved the settlement in September 2024.
- Malachi will receive 1.9 million shekels, while attorneys are awarded 8.06 million shekels in legal fees.
- Individual refunds are expected to range from several dozen to a few hundred shekels per user.
- Google will enhance transparency around auto-renewals and allow immediate cancellations with proportional refunds.

title: EU Details AI Act Scope and Bans Unacceptable Risk AI Systems
summary:
- As of February 2, 2025, the EU can ban AI systems posing 'unacceptable risk'.
- The first compliance deadline follows the EU’s AI Act, effective August 1, 2024.
- High-risk AI systems will have heavy oversight; unacceptable AI (e.g., social scoring) is prohibited.
- Fines for using banned AI could reach up to €35 million or 7% of annual revenue.
- Organizations must comply by February 2, with enforcement details in August 2025.
- The EU Commission issued guidance for compliance, with warnings of severe penalties.
- Guidelines are illustrative, not legally binding; enforcement handled by regulators.
- Adoption of guidelines awaits translation into EU languages.
- Future compliance deadlines are expected; Member States have until August 2 to appoint oversight bodies.
- The European Union has published guidance on defining AI systems under the AI Act.
- The risk-based framework regulating AI applications came into force last summer, with the first compliance deadline recently occurring.
- AI developers must determine if their software falls within the act’s scope to avoid fines of up to 7% of global annual turnover for breaches.
- The 13-page guidelines from the Commission are non-binding and subject to updates as the AI field evolves.
- The EU warns that there won't be exhaustive lists defining systems that fall within or outside the AI system definition.

sources.title: AI systems with ‘unacceptable risk’ are now banned in the EU
EU puts out guidance on uses of AI that are banned under its AI Act
EU details which systems fall within AI Act’s scope

title: US Immigration is Gaming Google to Create a Mirage of Mass Deportations
summary:

title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid
summary:
- Researchers discovered that renewable energy facilities in Central Europe use unencrypted radio signals for controlling power grid input and output.
- The system allows for the control of approximately 60 GW of energy, including both generation and load management.
- An optimally crafted series of messages could theoretically disable the entire European power grid, a potential risk they highlighted at the 38th Chaos Communication Congress.
- The communication protocol utilized is called Radio Ripple Control, which is based on an older protocol dating back to the early 1900s.
- No encryption is applied to the signals, allowing unauthorized users to intercept and manipulate them.

title: China's Online Merchants Consider Price Hikes Amid Tariffs
summary:

- Trump imposed a 10% tariff on goods from China, potentially affecting 335 million U.S. citizens relying on e-commerce.
- Trump acknowledged that Americans might experience 'some pain' from the tariffs.
- Experts warn that businesses sourcing from China may face significant challenges due to these tariffs.
- Chinese merchants are considering price hikes due to new tariffs and rising shipping costs.
- USPS has temporarily halted parcel shipments from China and Hong Kong.
- A seller reports a 35% increase in shipping fees for textiles and 25% for other goods starting Feb. 4.
- The recent tariff increase by President Trump raised Chinese goods' tariffs by 10% and eliminated the de minimis exemption.
- The de minimis exemption allowed packages under US$800 to enter duty-free, which significantly supported China's e-commerce growth.
- Nearly half of de minimis shipments originated from China, making this policy change a substantial setback for Chinese sellers.

title: AI Model s1 Competes with OpenAI’s o1 at a Fraction of the Cost
summary:
- AI researchers from Stanford and the University of Washington trained the AI reasoning model **s1** for under **$50** in cloud compute credits.
- **s1** performs comparably to advanced models like OpenAI's **o1** and DeepSeek's **R1**, particularly excelling in math and coding tests.
- The model, distilled from Google's Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking Experimental, is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/simplescaling/s1).
- It was trained on a dataset of **1,000** curated questions using cost-effective supervised fine-tuning (SFT).
- **s1** achieved strong benchmark results after a training time of less than **30 minutes** on **16 Nvidia H100 GPUs**, with total compute costs around **$20**.
- Major companies like Meta, Google, and Microsoft are projected to invest hundreds of billions in AI infrastructure by **2025**.
- The model was introduced on **Feb. 2** and reached state-of-the-art performance at a low training cost of **$6**.
- Training took **26 minutes** and utilized a distilled dataset from **Qwen2.5**.
- Innovations like **s1** promote experimentation with limited resources, raising discussions on ethical issues regarding **distilling** datasets from existing AI models.

sources.title: Researchers created an open rival to OpenAI’s o1 ‘reasoning’ model for under $50
AI model s1 rivals OpenAI’s o1 with $6 training cost

title: Researchers Benchmark AI Reasoning Using NPR's Sunday Puzzle
summary:

- Researchers from various colleges created a benchmark using around 600 riddles from the puzzle.
- AI models like OpenAI’s o1 and DeepSeek’s R1 were tested, revealing unexpected behaviors such as 'giving up' or providing incorrect answers.
- The best-performing model achieved a score of 59%, while higher reasoning effort models performed slightly lower.
- This study aims to create accessible reasoning benchmarks that don’t require advanced knowledge, promoting better understanding of AI capabilities.

sources.title: Researchers Benchmark AI Reasoning Using NPR's Sunday Puzzle

title: Bench burned through $135 million before shutting down

- In June 2024, Bench's biggest lender, the National Bank of Canada, provided over $40 million in loans, but the startup ultimately failed just weeks later.
- NBC was owed $51 million by Bench, and a potential acquisition by Employer.com is planned for February 28, 2025.

title: Why IQ is a poor test for AI
summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman noted AI's rapid improvement in IQ over recent years, suggesting an increase of about one standard deviation of IQ annually.
- Experts criticize IQ as a misleading measure for AI capabilities, emphasizing that IQ tests are based on human intelligence criteria, which do not apply to AI.
- Sandra Wachter points out the biases and limitations of IQ tests, arguing they oversimplify human intelligence and can lead to incorrect assumptions about AI's capabilities.
- AI potentially has an advantage on IQ tests due to its ability to process and memorize vast amounts of information from training data.
- Experts call for the development of better testing measures for AI that account for its unique problem-solving approaches, as current IQ tests are designed primarily for human evaluation.

sources.title: Why IQ is a poor test for AI

- Paragon sells spyware to government agencies, claiming to restrict sales to democratic nations.
- Casarini received a notification about the spyware while on a train, alongside 89 others.
- Paragon's hacking software, Graphite, can access all data on infected phones without user interaction.
- There is increasing scrutiny on Italy's potential use of the spyware, with calls to investigate the users and extent of the issue.
- WhatsApp indicated the surveillance began in December but provided no information on its duration.
- Mediterranea Saving Humans announced one of its founders, Luca Casarini, was targeted by Paragon spyware.
- WhatsApp disrupted a campaign targeting around 90 individuals, including journalists and civil society members, using Paragon spyware.
- Other targets include journalist Francesco Cancellato and activist Husam El Gomati, all critical of the current Italian government.

- Miist's inhaler delivers medication rapidly to the lungs, achieving a 92% craving reduction in smokers within two minutes during Phase I trials.

title: Figure Drops OpenAI in Favor of In-house Models and Details Plans for Humanoid Robot Safety
summary:
- Safety of humanoid robots is often overlooked in workplace integration.
- Figure AI is establishing a Center for the Advancement of Humanoid Safety, led by former Amazon Robotics safety engineer Rob Gruendel.
- The firm aims to certify robot safety standards in collaboration with OSHA recognized independent testing laboratories and improve safety measures for robotic systems working alongside humans.
- Figure AI CEO Brett Adcock announced the company is exiting its partnership with OpenAI to focus on in-house AI development.
- The decision follows a major breakthrough that promises to reveal something unprecedented in humanoid technology within 30 days.
- Figure has raised a total of $1.5 billion, with the last funding round valuing the company at $2.6 billion.
- OpenAI had previously collaborated with Figure on AI models for humanoid robots; Adcock cites integration challenges as a reason for the split.
- Figure will prioritize vertical integration for powering humanoid robots, contrasting with OpenAI's broader focus.
- OpenAI filed a trademark application hinting at developing humanoid robots, underscoring a potential shift in its own strategy.

title: Okta competitor SailPoint races toward $11.5B IPO
summary:

- SailPoint was previously public until being taken private by Thoma Bravo in 2022 at a $6.9 billion valuation.
- The company expects $813 million in annual recurring revenue and reported $395 million in net losses with $700 million in revenues as of January 2024.
- SailPoint has more than $1 billion in debt and plans to use IPO proceeds to address this debt and fund operations.
- The IPO's timing is significant for venture capitalists and tech startups looking for market signals for their own offerings.

title: Hugging Face researchers aim to build an ‘open’ version of OpenAI’s deep research tool
summary:
- Researchers at Hugging Face have developed an open version called Open Deep Research, based on OpenAI’s deep research tool.
- OpenAI's original tool is part of a $200/month ChatGPT Pro plan and compiles research reports by crawling the web.
- Open Deep Research incorporates OpenAI's o1 model and an open-source framework, allowing for autonomous web navigation and analysis.
- Initial tests showed Open Deep Research achieving a GAIA benchmark score of 54%, compared to 67.36% for OpenAI’s tool.
- A public demo was launched but faced high traffic issues, with users experiencing errors during testing.
- The source code for Open Deep Research is available on GitHub for further development and user feedback.

title: Chinese AI Reasoning Model Competes with OpenAI's o1 and DeepSeek Banned in Australia
summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, is banned from all federal government devices in Australia due to national security risks.
- The directive was signed by the home affairs department secretary after intelligence agency advice.
- The Albanese government emphasizes protective actions regarding national security and potential threats posed by AI technologies.
- Australia joins other countries like Taiwan and Italy in banning DeepSeek from government devices.
- Similar to previous bans on TikTok, discussions and considerations regarding DeepSeek's risks are ongoing within government systems.

- Chinese reasoning model R1 reportedly outperforms OpenAI's o1 on several benchmarks.
- DeepSeek, Alibaba, and Moonshot AI claim their models match o1's capabilities.
- R1 has restrictions on certain topics due to Chinese Internet regulations when run in the cloud.

title: Tapestry: A New Multi-Feed App by Iconfactory
summary:
- After Elon Musk's takeover, Twitter blocked third-party clients in 2023.
- Iconfactory launches the multi-feed app Tapestry, supporting sources like RSS, YouTube, and more.
- Tapestry raised over $177,000 on Kickstarter in January 2025 and emphasizes user data privacy.
- Users can customize feeds and create rules to mute specific content.
- The app offers subscription features for creating multiple feeds and removing ads at various price points.
- A new app called [Tapestry](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/tapestry-by-iconfactory/id6448078074) launched on February 4, 2025, to aggregate and organize information from across the web.
- It aims to reduce the need for app-switching by providing a single platform for updates from various social networks and RSS feeds.
- The app is built by the creators of the original Twitter client, Twitterrific, and introduces a customizable timeline feature.
- Users can filter content and create custom timelines for specific interests such as news or social networks.
- While it offers a unique solution, the app's user interface can feel complicated, and requires users to engage in feed creation.
- Tapestry faces competition from other apps like [Bluesky](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/03/what-is-bluesky-everything-to-know-about-the-x-competitor/) and [Flipboard's Surf](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/18/flipboard-launches-surf-a-new-app-for-browsing-the-open-social-web/).

title: Threads Enhances Custom Feeds in Response to Bluesky Competition
summary:
- X, formerly known as Twitter, sees declining daily active users, leading to increased interest in alternatives like [Bluesky](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/16/what-is-bluesky-everything-to-know-about-the-x-competitor/), [Mastodon](https://techcrunch.com/2023/07/24/what-is-mastodon/), and [Threads](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/16/what-is-instagrams-threads-app-all-your-questions-answered/).
- To delete an X account, users can download their data and deactivate their account with a 30-day grace period.
- Meta’s Threads introduces public custom feeds to enhance user experience and compete with Bluesky, which has over 30 million users.
- Users can create, share, and follow public custom feeds based on various topics and pin them to their home screen.

summary:

- 40% of companies plan workforce reductions due to AI, but two-thirds aim to hire talent with specific AI skills.

- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman discussed AI automation with SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son in Tokyo.

summary:

- Fund II attracted 300 operator LPs and six institutional investors, building on the success of the first fund launched in 2021, which included 250 operators and backed notable companies such as AI composer Writer and data center tech Atlan.

title: Deepfake videos are getting shockingly good
summary:
- Researchers from ByteDance demonstrated a new AI system, [OmniHuman-1](https://omnihuman-lab.github.io/), which generates highly realistic deepfake videos.
- Unlike previous deepfakes, OmniHuman-1 can produce convincing videos using just one reference image and audio.
- The system shows significant improvements but still struggles with low-quality images and certain poses.
- Deepfakes have been part of spreading misinformation and financial fraud, causing substantial losses in recent years.
- An open letter from the AI community calls for strict regulations on deepfakes; some states are enacting laws against AI impersonation.
- Public concern is rising as a survey indicates 60% of people encountered deepfakes in the past year, with many fearing they could be misled.

- CEO Boris Paskalev emphasizes the goal to resolve software bugs more effectively than current AI models by utilizing a test-driven development approach.
- The startup's technology currently supports Python, with plans to expand to Typescript, Javascript, and Java, targeting enterprises for implementation.

title: Spotify reports its first full year of profitability, adds 35M monthly active users
summary:
- Spotify announced its fourth-quarter earnings, achieving its first full year of profitability after 17 years.
- Operating income for Q4 reached €477 million ($509.48 million), totaling €1.4 billion ($1.495 billion) for fiscal year 2024.
- The company added 35 million monthly active users, bringing the total to 675 million, a 12% year-over-year increase, exceeding projections of 25 million.
- Total paid subscribers rose to 263 million, up from 240 million despite recent price hikes on Premium subscriptions.
- Plans for a HiFi or “super premium” subscription tier were teased, potentially increasing monthly costs by around $5.
- Spotify signed a new multi-year distribution agreement with Universal Music Group, aimed at protecting streaming royalties and enabling new offerings for fans.

title: What’s behind Nintendo’s 42% drop in profits?
summary:
- Nintendo’s profits fell by 42% to 237 billion yen ($1.5 billion) from the previous year, driven by declining Switch console sales.
- Sales dropped 31% to 956 billion yen ($6 billion) for the nine-month period, with total console sales declining from 13.7 million to 9.54 million units.
- The company revised its profit forecast for the fiscal year down to 270 billion yen ($1.7 billion) from 300 billion yen ($1.9 billion).
- Nintendo plans to sell 11 million Switch consoles for the full year, down from an initial projection of 12.5 million.
- Despite declining sales, over 100 million Switch players remain, and Nintendo is launching the successor, Switch 2, later this year.
- The opening of Super Nintendo World in May 2024 is expected to draw interest in Nintendo's content.

title: OpenAI’s Operator agent helped me move, but I had to help it, too
summary:
- OpenAI's new AI agent, Operator, was tested over one week for task automation on the internet.
- Operator can perform basic tasks such as navigating websites and filling out forms but requires significant user assistance.
- The agent operates like cruise control rather than full autopilot, needing frequent user input and intervention.
- While some companies (like Instacart and eBay) support Operator, others (like TaskRabbit and YouTube) block its access.
- Trust issues arise due to instances of hallucination that could lead to costly mistakes, making users hesitant to rely solely on the AI agent.

title: Sotira lands $2M to help brands offload and monetize their surplus inventory
summary:
- Sotira aims to tackle the surplus inventory issue, which is estimated to be 20%-30% of all inventory in the U.S.
- The startup has raised $2 million in pre-seed funding to expand operations nationwide, focusing on the Midwest and Southeast.
- Sotira uses AI to help brands offload surplus grocery, health, and cosmetics products quickly and efficiently.
- The founders, Amrita Bhasin and Gary Kwong, have a background in e-commerce and logistics, having previously run liquidation businesses.
- Suppliers can match their overstock with buyers through Sotira, which automates compliance and logistics to facilitate fast transactions.
- Sotira charges a monthly fee and takes a percentage of the revenue from each transaction on its platform.
- The company offers affordable access to premium products for consumers, especially in rural areas.
- Sotira plans to expand its services to the apparel industry in the future.

- Features powered by this model will include AI Snaps and AI Bitmoji Backgrounds, set to launch in the coming months.

title: 22-year-old math wiz indicted for alleged DeFI hack that stole $65M
summary:
- A man named Andean Medjedovic was indicted for allegedly stealing $65 million in cryptocurrency through two DeFI hacks.
- The incidents occurred in 2021 and 2023, involving KyberSwap and Indexed Finance platforms.
- Medjedovic exploited smart contract vulnerabilities and used manipulative trading practices to maximize his theft, stealing approximately $48.8 million from 77 liquidity pools.
- He attempted to extort developers and return part of the stolen funds in exchange for control of the KyberSwap protocol.
- Efforts to launder the proceeds included using cryptocurrency mixers and bridge protocols, but a mishap led to his arrest.

title: EFishery Confirms Fraud Allegations and Restructuring by FTI Consulting
summary:
- eFishery suspended co-founders Gibran Huzaifah and Chrisna Aditya in December 2024 amid fraud claims.
- An audit report identifies 10 senior executives as "implicated employees" in falsifying financials and executing fake transactions.
- Key implicated individuals include former CEO Huzaifah, VP Angga Hadrian Raditya, and senior VP Kristin Dax Veriga.
- Six others were aware of inflated figures but did not report them to the board.
- Fraud involved bonuses based on inflated financials totaling $1.3 million and schemes to mislead auditors.
- FTI Consulting is conducting the ongoing investigation and has not yet interviewed all individuals mentioned in the report.
- The board confirmed misconduct allegations, and FTI Consulting will take over as acting management after receiving shareholder approval.
- The company plans a thorough business review; the number of layoffs is currently unclear.

title: OpenAI Expands in Asia with Kakao Partnership Following SoftBank Deal
summary:
- Kakao Corp. partners with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT and AI services into KakaoTalk.
- Announcement made during OpenAI CEO Sam Altman’s visit to Seoul.
- Focus on developing joint products and applying OpenAI’s technology across Kakao’s platforms.
- Partnership aims to commercialize AI and collaborate with local tech firms.
- Altman is touring Asia and announced a similar partnership with SoftBank in Tokyo.
- Plans to meet with tech leaders from SK Group, SK Telecom, SK Hynix, and Samsung Electronics.
- OpenAI announces a partnership with Kakao to expand its presence in Asia, focusing on Korean language content.
- The collaboration will result in the creation of a Korean-language assistant named Kanana and integration of OpenAI technology into KakaoTalk.
- This announcement follows SoftBank's commitment of $3 billion to implement OpenAI technology across its operations and the establishment of a joint venture called SB OpenAI Japan.
- OpenAI aims to enhance its AI capabilities by gaining access to more Asian-language data and user behavior.

title: Opera launches a mindfulness-focused browser with break reminders and soundscapes

title: From the Experts: tackling the top IP challenges for businesses

title: Meta says it may stop development of AI systems it deems too risky
summary:
• Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg aims to make artificial general intelligence (AGI) open in the future.
• Meta's new Frontier AI Framework categorizes AI systems as "high-risk" or "critical-risk" based on their potential for harm.
• High-risk systems may assist in attacks but are less reliable, while critical-risk systems could result in catastrophic outcomes.
• Meta's classification relies on input from researchers rather than empirical tests, due to lack of robust evaluation metrics.
• If a system is deemed high-risk, internal access will be limited; critical-risk systems will halt development until mitigations are in place.
• Meta's approach contrasts with companies like OpenAI, as it has previously released AI models openly, leading to both successes and security concerns.

sources.title: Meta says it may stop development of AI systems it deems too risky

title: India cuts import tax on smartphone parts
summary:
- India has removed import duties on components needed for mobile phone manufacturing as announced by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Feb. 1.
- The decision is intended to support domestic production and benefit companies like Apple and Xiaomi.
- Duty exemptions now apply to components like printed circuit board assemblies, camera module parts, and USB cables, which had a previous tax of 2.5%.
- The policy aims to enhance India’s global competitiveness and establish it as a major manufacturing hub, competing with China and Vietnam.

summary:

- The AI model contributed to a decline in the Nasdaq index recently.
- Liang leads a team of 139, smaller than major competitors like OpenAI.
- He attended a meeting with Premier Li Qiang on Jan. 27, aiming to make AI more accessible.

- Wenfeng is a billionaire hedge fund manager known for his research showing AI models can be built with fewer Nvidia chips, crucial for China.

title: Crypto Exchanges Kraken and Deribit Experience Record Growth in 2024
summary:
- Deribit reported a trading volume of US$1.1 trillion for 2024, up 95% from US$608 billion in 2023.
- The exchange recorded a peak 24-hour volume of US$14.8 billion on Nov. 12, following the US presidential election.
- Open interest reached US$48 billion on Nov. 28, coinciding with bitcoin prices exceeding US$100,000.
- Options trading increased by 99% in notional volumes, with spot trading up by 810% to US$7.6 billion.
- December 2024 was marked as the busiest trading month since November 2021, driven by Bitcoin and Ethereum ETFs and renewed interest in memecoins.
- Deribit relocated to Dubai, complying with the Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority and adopting the FATF Travel Rule for anti-money laundering.
- Kraken's revenue has increased to $1.5 billion in 2024, marking significant growth compared to previous years.
- Key factors for Kraken's revenue growth include increased trading volumes and expansion into new markets.

title: India expands Aadhaar authentication for businesses, raising privacy concerns
summary:
- India has eased restrictions on its Aadhaar authentication service for businesses across various sectors.  
- The Indian IT ministry introduced new rules allowing wider use of Aadhaar for service delivery as of February 2, 2025.  
- These changes have raised privacy concerns, especially regarding the safeguarding of biometric data and the potential for misuse.  
- The amendment comes two years after public consultation, with responses undisclosed.  
- The amendment broadens authentication services, previously limited mostly to banking and telecom industries.  
- In January, Aadhaar authentication transactions reached 129.93 billion, an increase from the previous year.  
- New applications for Aadhaar authentication will need approval from the Indian government based on UIDAI's recommendations.  
- Experts are calling for clearer guidelines to prevent misuse and ensure transparency in the application process.

sources.title: India expands Aadhaar authentication for businesses, raising privacy concerns

title: Trump's Tariff Revisions Could Impact US Economy and Tech Pricing
summary:
- Trump is considering revisions to tariffs that could impact tech product pricing.
- The changes may lead to increased costs for consumers and businesses in the tech sector.
- Analysts suggest this could exacerbate existing supply chain issues and inflation concerns.
- Proposed tariffs on semiconductors could backfire and harm the US economy.
- Tariffs may lead to increased costs for US consumers, potentially contributing to inflation.
- Concerns raised that Taiwanese companies might shift production abroad, possibly leading to a global tariff war.

- Previous tariffs affected key semiconductor producers from Mexico, Canada, and China.

title: Korean automaker faces trademark battle in Turkey
summary:
- South Korean car manufacturer KG Mobility (formerly SsangYong Motor) is involved in a trademark dispute in Turkey.
- The Turkish Patent and Trademark Office has temporarily prohibited Cihan Turan, the trademark owner, from transferring rights since last month.
- The legal battle over trademark invalidation may last 2 to 4 years, leading to significant costs and delays.
- Turkey is a key market alongside Europe and Korea, making the dispute significant for KG Mobility.
- The company must pay royalties to use its name, complicating matters further.
- Ongoing negotiations with Turan are taking place in the EU.
- KG Mobility's alternative acronym “KGM” was rejected in Turkey due to similarities with Turkey’s General Directorate of Highways.

- This initiative mirrors Apple’s earlier steps in Russia regarding recommended government apps.

title: Bitcoin Mining Profit Falls Amid Harsh US Cold Snap
summary:
- Bitcoin's mining difficulty decreased on Jan. 27, marking the first drop since late September 2024.
- The decrease was influenced by a cold snap in the US, which raised energy prices and reduced mining profitability.
- The US holds 46% of the global Bitcoin mining hashrate, with Texas contributing 17%.
- Increased demand for natural gas and reliance on renewable energy in Texas led to higher electricity costs for mining firms.
- Miner revenue per terahash declined in January compared to December, indicating financial strain.
- Companies like Riot Platforms are seeking diversification by using mining infrastructure for AI and high-performance tasks.
- Analysts predict stability in Bitcoin's mining hashrate as US weather conditions improve.

sources.title: Bitcoin Mining Profit Falls Amid Harsh US Cold Snap

title: Dub: the copy trading app that has teens talking
summary:
- Dub is a copy trading app that allows users to mimic the trades of top investors.
- The app was founded by 23-year-old Steven Wang and has gained over 800,000 downloads and raised $17 million in seed funding.
- Dub operates on a subscription model, charging $10 per month, and takes a 25% cut of management fees from top portfolios.
- Wang emphasizes user education, providing risk scores and portfolio metrics to help informed decision-making.
- Critics argue that active stock picking underperforms passive investing; however, Wang contests these claims, citing the success of hedge funds.

title: AI tools used for child sexual abuse images targeted in Home Office crackdown
summary:
- Britain is set to become the first country to impose laws against the use of [AI tools for creating child sexual abuse images](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2024/oct/18/artificial-intelligence-child-sexual-abuse-imagery-watchdog-iwf).
- New legislation will make it illegal to possess, create, or distribute AI tools for generating such material, with prison sentences of up to five years for offenders.
- Possession of instructional manuals on using AI for abuse will also be illegal, facing potential three-year prison terms.
- Website operators sharing abusive materials will be targeted under the new laws, alongside strengthened powers for the Border Force to inspect digital devices of suspected offenders.
- Reports of AI-generated child sexual abuse imagery have surged from 51 in 2023 to 245 last year, as per the Internet Watch Foundation (IWF).
- Concerns grow that AI tools could normalize child sexual abuse, with police warning of a direct link between viewing such imagery and real-life abuse.
- Technology Secretary Peter Kyle emphasized the need for urgent legislative action to keep children safe from AI-related exploitation.

sources.title: AI tools used for child sexual abuse images targeted in Home Office crackdown

title: Microsoft patches Windows to eliminate Secure Boot bypass threat
summary:
- Microsoft patched a vulnerability in Secure Boot tracked as CVE-2024-7344 that allowed attackers to run malicious firmware during boot.
- The vulnerability could be exploited by those with privileged access, leading to persistent malware that evades OS defenses.
- Secure Boot, established in 2012, prevents these attacks by verifying digital signatures of firmware components during the boot process.

sources.title: Microsoft patches Windows to eliminate Secure Boot bypass threat

title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom
summary:
- A New Zealand sheep farmer, Samuel Butler, predicted AI safety concerns such as machine consciousness and self-replication over 161 years ago.
- His writings influenced themes in later works like Asimov's and Frank Herbert's novels.
- Butler's 1872 novel, Erewhon, illustrated a society that banned machines invented within the last 300 years due to concerns about machine evolution.
- He emphasized the relationship between the evolution of machines and Darwinian principles, expressing admiration for Darwin's work.
- Despite being written in a time of rudimentary calculating devices, Butler's predictions about machine intelligence have proven to be remarkably insightful and relevant today.

sources.title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom

title: US splits world into three tiers for AI chip access
summary:
- The US government announced new regulations on global AI chip exports, dividing the world into three tiers of access.
- The rules impose quotas for about 120 countries and allow unrestricted access for 18 close US allies while banning China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.
- New regulations build on previous chip controls from September 2022 and October 2023, set to take effect in 120 days.
- First-tier countries face no restrictions, while second-tier countries can receive a limited number of advanced computing chips based on agreements with the US.
- Orders of up to 1,700 advanced chips do not require licenses, facilitating purchases by educational and medical institutions.

sources.title: US splits world into three tiers for AI chip access

title: Widely used DNA sequencer still doesn’t enforce Secure Boot
summary:
- In 2012, an industry coalition adopted Secure Boot to protect devices against malware.
- Secure Boot uses public-key cryptography to prevent unauthorized code from loading.
- Microsoft requires Secure Boot for Windows devices, but not for specialized devices like the Illumina iSeq 100 DNA sequencer.
- The iSeq 100 can boot from legacy BIOS and uses outdated firmware with critical vulnerabilities.
- Firmware Read/Write protections are not enabled, allowing potential firmware modifications by attackers.
- The vulnerabilities could affect a broad range of devices using similar OEM motherboards.

sources.title: Widely used DNA sequencer still doesn’t enforce Secure Boot

summary:

- The computer features the GB10 Grace Blackwell Superchip, a combination of an Nvidia Blackwell GPU and a 20-core Grace CPU.
- Project DIGITS can run AI models with up to 200 billion parameters, and two linked units can handle models with 405 billion parameters, aiming to provide local AI capabilities.

- The malicious version (24.10.4) was pushed through a spear phishing email to developers.
- Other affected extensions were identified, totaling 19 having 1.46 million downloads.
- Organizations are encouraged to re-evaluate security protocols for browser extensions due to these vulnerabilities.

summary:

summary:
- STMicroelectronics plans to cut 2,000 to 3,000 jobs, representing up to 6% of its workforce, due to ongoing industry challenges.

title: DeepSeek Faces Trademark Conflict While US Seeks AI Talent from China
summary:
- Chinese AI company DeepSeek is facing a potential trademark conflict in the U.S.
- DeepSeek filed a trademark application for its AI chatbot apps, but another company, Delson Group, applied for the same trademark just 36 hours earlier.
- Delson Group claims to have been selling DeepSeek-branded AI products since early 2020 and may have advantages in proving trademark rights.
- DeepSeek's options may be limited, as U.S. law favors the first user of a trademark unless bad faith can be demonstrated.
- Delson Group’s CEO, Willie Lu, has a history of trademark disputes and operates a course on AI Super-Intelligence under the same name.
- Washington lawmakers are looking to engage top AI talent from China to remain competitive in AI.
- Melanie Hart from the Atlantic Council advocated for attracting engineers from the Chinese start-up DeepSeek.
- The committee highlighted the need to protect intellectual property and national security while acquiring talent.

- Market capitalization rose by 32% to AED 907 billion (US$246 billion) by December 2024.
- Revenue increased by 15.5% to AED 632.3 million (US$172.15 million), while expenses slightly rose to AED 223 million (US$60.71 million).
- A cash dividend of AED 256 million (US$69.7 million) was proposed, amounting to 97% of retained earnings.
- The DFM welcomed 138,262 new investors, marking a 120.5% increase, with 85% being foreign nationals.

summary:
- South Korea’s Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC) is investigating DeepSeek's management of user personal data.
- A written request for information will be sent to DeepSeek’s operators on Jan. 31, 2025.
- Regulatory authorities in France, Italy, and Ireland are also investigating DeepSeek's data practices.
- The investigation is part of ongoing concerns about personal data management.

summary:

title: Indian seafood startup raises $28.84m pre-IPO, aims for $1b
summary:
- Captain Fresh has raised ₹250 crore (US$28.84 million) in its pre-IPO funding round.
- Funding led by Prosus Ventures, Accel, and Tiger Global, with participation from notable investors like Swiggy co-founder Sriharsha Majety.
- Founded in 2020, Captain Fresh has seen a fivefold growth and became PAT positive in the last two quarters.
- The company aims for US$550 million in revenue for FY 2025 and targets US$1 billion in revenue within the next 12 months as it prepares for an IPO.

title: X expands lawsuit over advertiser ‘boycott’ to include Lego, Nestlé, Pinterest, and others
summary:
- X, formerly Twitter, expands its antitrust lawsuit claiming a systematic illegal boycott by advertisers.
- The lawsuit was initially filed in August 2024 against the World Federation of Advertisers and its Global Alliance of Responsible Media initiative.
- The complaint now includes companies like Nestlé, Lego, and Pinterest, alleging coordinated efforts to harm X's advertising revenue.
- At least 18 GARM-affiliated advertisers reportedly stopped advertising on X between November and December 2022.
- X claims reduced ad spending and lower prices due to the boycott, harming its revenue from small and medium-sized businesses.

sources.title: X expands lawsuit over advertiser ‘boycott’ to include Lego, Nestlé, Pinterest, and others

title: ‘I lost 10 years of my life’: how UK betting giant’s unlawful marketing kept suicidal gambler hooked
summary:
- Sam logged into his online betting account on 15 August 2018, gambling five days’ worth of wages despite being deep in debt.
- Sky Betting & Gaming labeled him as a ‘high value’ customer and sent targeted promotional emails, prompting further gambling. 
- A landmark legal ruling found that the targeting was unlawful, as Sam was not in a state to consent due to his compulsive gambling behavior.
- The judge concluded that Sam's decision-making was impaired and highlighted Sky Bet's failure to identify at-risk customers for intervention.

sources.title: ‘I lost 10 years of my life’: how UK betting giant’s unlawful marketing kept suicidal gambler hooked

title: Adobe exec Scott Belsky departs for indie movie studio A24
summary:

- He has been with Adobe since 2012, initially through the acquisition of Behance.
- A24 is known for critically acclaimed films and has won Oscars for "Everything Everywhere All At Once" and "Moonlight."
- Belsky mentioned he will be working on special projects at A24, aiming to support the studio's storytelling efforts.

sources.title: Adobe exec Scott Belsky departs for indie movie studio A24

title: DeepSeek gets Silicon Valley talking
summary:
- DeepSeek went viral due to its AI models sparking discussions about the U.S. maintaining its lead in AI and the sustainability of AI chip demand.
- DeepSeek claims its R1 reasoning model performs on par with OpenAI’s o1 model on key benchmarks.
- American teens have expressed low trust in Big Tech, with a majority believing companies do not prioritize their well-being or ethical decisions regarding AI.

title: Here are all the IPOs reported to be in the works for 2025
summary:
- Tech companies are optimistic about going public in 2025 due to a new presidential administration easing regulations.
- Notable companies filing for IPOs include eToro, Voyager Technologies, and Karman Holdings, all filed in January 2025.
- Several companies are looking to go public after prior confidential filings, including Chime, Klarna, and Genesys, with potential IPOs planned in 2025.

title: DeepSeek's AI Innovations Raise Concerns about U.S. Competitiveness
summary:
- DeepSeek developed advanced AI models with less computing power, stirring U.S. AI competitiveness concerns.
- The training cost for its model totaled $5.6 million but actual expenses are unclear due to initial investment needs.
- Techniques like Mixture-of-experts and chain-of-thought reasoning are now questioned for their uniqueness.
- The smaller R1 model demonstrated spontaneous reasoning capabilities with reduced resources, enhancing training efficiency interest.
- Nvidia's shares dropped 17% following the implications of DeepSeek's developments, with worries about high-end GPU demand.
- Allegations surfaced regarding potential inappropriate use of OpenAI models for training, though unverified.
- Breakthroughs could lead to efficient AI applications on consumer devices, attracting interest from companies like Apple.
- OpenAI launched ChatGPT Gov, focusing on secure AI deployment for U.S. government agencies.
- According to Marc Andreessen, DeepSeek R1 is noted as AI's 'Sputnik moment'.
- A Chinese startup introduced a competitive chatbot at lower costs, jeopardizing U.S. tech supremacy, leading to nearly $600bn loss in Nvidia shares.
- DeepSeek’s app became the most downloaded free app in the US and UK stores, facing initial app store challenges in Italy over data privacy.
- Experts were impressed by DeepSeek's challenge to traditional AI development, prioritizing skills and computing efficiency.
- U.S. officials are urged to intensify efforts on AI competitiveness amid these developments.

sources.title: After a week of DeepSeek freakout, doubts and mysteries remain
Was this the week DeepSeek started the slow unwinding of the AI bet?

title: AI Advances Spark Concerns Over U.S. Semiconductor Policy and Chinese Competitive Edge
summary:
- US President Donald Trump met Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang at the White House on January 31 to discuss AI and semiconductor exports.
- The meeting is part of the US's consideration of stricter restrictions on AI chip exports to China.
- Trump described the meeting as 'good', focusing on semiconductor and AI policy amid concerns over China's advancements in AI.
- Nvidia experienced a historic one-day market cap loss of $600bn, affecting many tech companies.
- Chinese startup DeepSeek launched R1, a cheap and effective AI assistant, costing $5.58m to develop.
- R1 outperforms competitors in efficiency and has drawn significant interest from users and investors alike.
- Marc Andreessen called R1 AI's "Sputnik moment," indicating its potential to disrupt US tech.
- DeepSeek’s success reflects China's advancement in AI technology and raises concerns for US companies.
- The rollout of R1 shows low-cost AI models could transform the industry, similar to past technological revolutions.

sources.title: Trump calls meeting with Nvidia CEO ‘good’ on AI policy
AI is not just powerful. What’s really worrying is that DeepSeek has made it cheap, too

title: Venture debt lenders will play a big role in fire sales and startup shutdown this year, experts say
summary:
- The accounting startup Bench failed after lenders called in the loan, leaving many businesses without accounting access.
- Venture lending firm Hercules Capital took control of digital freight company Convoy due to financial challenges.
- Venture debt reached a record $53.3 billion in 2024, with major funding for AI companies like CoreWeave and OpenAI.
- Experts predict many startups will be forced into fire sales or shutdowns in 2025 as lenders push for acquisitions to minimize losses.
- The risks associated with venture debt are significant, especially for underperforming startups potentially facing foreclosure or forced sales.

title: Apps Competing to Be the ‘TikTok for Bluesky’ with Focus on Video Features
summary:
- Reelo is a video-first app for the open-source social network [Bluesky](https://techcrunch.com/2024/09/10/what-is-bluesky-everything-to-know-about-the-app-trying-to-replace-twitter/).
- Built on the AT Protocol, Reelo supports longer videos, filters, and livestreaming.
- Developer João Davi Souza Nascimento aims for a March 20, 2025, launch focused on creator tools and monetization.
- Videos can be up to three minutes long with a swipeable vertical feed.
- Users can interoperate with Bluesky, posting videos as an optional feature.
- The potential U.S. ban on TikTok has spurred the development of Bluesky-focused video apps.
- Other apps in development include Bluescreen, Skylight, and Videos for Bluesky.
- Skylight aims for a TikTok-like experience but is limited by video restrictions.
- Videos for Bluesky features vertical video browsing with trending videos.
- Flipboard's Surf app personalizes video feed offerings across the social web.
- BlueSky Reels focuses on curated video feeds and potential moderation similar to Reddit.

sources.title: Reelo stands out among the apps building a ‘TikTok for Bluesky’

title: Comparing AI Assistants: OpenAI's o3-mini vs DeepSeek and Others
summary:
- OpenAI is launching a new AI model called o3-mini for free on 31 January 2025, addressing competition from China’s DeepSeek.
- The o3-mini will provide reasoning capabilities to free users and offer enhanced access for ChatGPT Pro users.
- DeepSeek's R1 chatbot, impacting US tech company investor confidence, was released on January 20, 2025.
- o3-mini claims to match its predecessor in quality while improving response times and lowering costs.
- ChatGPT demonstrated improvement in handling complex prompts after initial challenges.
- DeepSeek refrained from discussing sensitive political issues during testing.
- Other tested chatbots include Grok, known for humorous responses, and Gemini, which struggled with specific queries despite being competent in interpreting images.

title: ‘Are we dating the same guy?’: Women turn to Facebook to uncover cheating and violence
summary:
- The Facebook group 'Are We Dating the Same Guy?' allows women to share information about men, especially focusing on potential cheaters and abusers.
- Groups are regional, with membership sizes varying from 164,000 in NYC to around 10,000 in Sydney; a UK group covers all regions.
- The groups serve as a resource for women to warn each other about dangerous men and discuss experiences with emotional abuse and narcissism.
- Some experts warn about the risks of backlash from men discovered through these groups, including legal threats and retaliatory actions.
- The conversation surrounding the Domestic Violence Disclosure Scheme (DVDS) emphasizes the importance of police disclosing information about abusive partners.
- Despite the potential dangers, the existence of the groups reflects a gap left by state services, showcasing women's solidarity and resourcefulness in protecting one another.

title: DeepSeek costs $500m, not publicly stated $6m: analysts
summary:
- Analysts estimate DeepSeek’s total hardware investment exceeds US$500 million, significantly higher than the publicly stated US$6 million pre-training cost.
- The US$6 million figure only accounts for GPU pre-training, excluding research, development, data preparation, and maintenance costs.
- DeepSeek has a workforce of approximately 150 and recruits top graduates with salaries over US$1.3 million annually.
- Backed by hedge fund High-Flyer, DeepSeek initially secured nearly 10,000 A100 GPUs and now operates around 50,000 GPUs, including H800 and restricted H20 models.
- Recent developments include concerns over DeepSeek-R1 generating biased content and facing global data security restrictions.

title: SEA healthtech funding drops to lowest level in 7 years; UAE firm boosts pre-series A to $7m

- The firm aims to enhance its healthcare services and expand its operations.
- Southeast Asia's healthtech sector raised just US$123 million in 2024, a 79% decrease from 2023.
- Singapore accounted for 75% of total funding with US$92 million.
- Overall funding in Asia fell by 11% due to macroeconomic uncertainties.
- Q2 2024 saw peak funding of US$41.2 million, down 63% year-over-year.
- HealthifyMe secured the highest funding at US$20 million.
- No deals exceeded US$100 million in 2024.
- IPO activity decreased with only two listings and eight acquisitions, including Nvidia’s acquisition of VinBrain.

- The startup has raised approximately $50 million, with potential for further investment.
- Echo Neurotechnologies specializes in brain-machine interfaces enabling patients to control devices using implanted electrodes.
- Chang has contributed to brain implant advancements, including a project allowing a paralyzed woman to communicate with AI.

- Roman Romantsov, founder of StarLadder, will continue as head of the subsidiary and become a shareholder in Nodwin Gaming.
- StarLadder, established in 2018, hosts international tournaments for games like Dota 2, PUBG, and Hearthstone.
- This deal follows Nazara's earlier investment of approximately $7.38 million into Nodwin Gaming to enhance its capabilities.
- As of November 2024, Nodwin's valuation was reported at $410 million.

- Investment driven by increasing demand for high-performance computing due to AI advancements.
- DataBank operates over 65 data centers in 27 markets and has raised $5 billion in capital in the past 18 months.
- The industry is anticipated to see capital expenditures exceed $250 billion in the next five years according to a McKinsey report.
- Cipher Mining received a $50 million investment from SoftBank, acquiring about 10.4 million shares.
- The investment will support Cipher's expansion into high-performance computing and AI data center hosting.
- Cipher is the tenth-largest public bitcoin miner with a market valuation of $1.6 billion.
- The company aims to reduce exposure to cryptocurrency market volatility while addressing AI solution demand.

title: Japan plans to expand export controls on chips, quantum tech
summary:
- Japan is expanding export controls to include advanced semiconductor chips and quantum computing technology.
- Proposed changes require companies to obtain licenses for exporting advanced chips, lithography equipment, and quantum cryocoolers.
- The government aims to prevent use of these technologies in weapons development and advanced encryption-breaking systems.
- New restrictions will take effect at the end of May 2025.
- Japan will add 42 new entities to its export oversight list, totaling around 110 Chinese companies and institutions.
- China has criticized these measures, warning of potential disruptions to supply chain security and economic relations.
- This action aligns with the U.S. tightening restrictions on chip sales for AI applications amid concerns over re-exportation to China.

sources.title: Japan plans to expand export controls on chips, quantum tech

title: Apple AI expands to 8 more languages in 2025
summary:
- Apple’s AI platform, Apple Intelligence, will support eight additional languages starting in April 2025: French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Japanese, Korean, and simplified Chinese.
- The announcement was made during CEO Tim Cook's Q4 2024 earnings call on January 30.
- This expansion follows the initial 2024 release, which supported only US English.
- In December 2024, localized English variants were added for Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa, and the UK, along with tailored versions for India and Singapore.
- No plans have been announced to expand Apple Intelligence to the European Union or Mainland China.
- An updated version of Siri is also in the works to improve context understanding, expected in the coming months.

sources.title: Apple AI expands to 8 more languages in 2025

title: Barbie joins digital learning app for interactive education
summary:
- Barbie brand will be integrated into Kiddopia, a digital learning app, later this year.
- The app will feature Barbie-themed educational games.
- The partnership aims to combine education with entertainment to create interactive learning experiences.
- Kiddopia, founded in 2012, operates primarily in the US and focuses on theme-based learning.
- In December 2024, Kiddopia partnered with Moonbug Entertainment to add the 'Little Angel' property.
- Nazara Technologies acquired Paper Boat Apps for 300 crore rupees (approximately US$34.60 million) in 2024.
- Nazara Technologies is expanding its gaming and digital entertainment presence and raised 495 crore rupees (US$57.1 million) to support growth.

title: LinkedIn Faces Lawsuit Over AI Training Usage Dismissed
summary:
- LinkedIn was targeted by a proposed class action lawsuit from Premium users alleging unauthorized use of private messages for AI training.
- Filed on Jan. 23, 2025, the lawsuit challenged a privacy policy update from September 2024 that allowed user data to be used for AI, specifying opting out wouldn't affect prior data use.
- Plaintiffs sought damages for breach of contract and violations of California’s unfair competition law, claiming the update concealed violations and reduced LinkedIn's legal responsibility.

- A separate lawsuit regarding LinkedIn's InMail data for AI training was dismissed when filed by Alessandro De La Torre, who withdrew it voluntarily on Jan. 30.
- Evidence showed that LinkedIn did not use private messages for AI training, and the company's legal team confirmed this.
- The case closed without prejudice, leaving the door open for possible future claims.

sources.title: LinkedIn sued over alleged InMail data use for AI training
LinkedIn lawsuit over AI training dismissed

• Nintendo's market capitalization has surpassed US$87 billion, aided by successful content strategies and expansion into movies and theme parks.

title: Autonomous Vehicle Testing Drops 50% in California; Waymo to Expand Robotaxi Services in 2025
summary:
- Waymo plans to test autonomous vehicles in 10 new cities in 2025, starting with [Las Vegas](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/29/waymo-reportedly-testing-robotaxis-in-10-new-cities-in-2025/) and [San Diego](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/29/waymo-reportedly-testing-robotaxis-in-10-new-cities-in-2025/).
- Less than 10 AVs will be sent to each city, with no confirmation of autonomous mode testing.
- Waymo operates a commercial robotaxi service in Phoenix, San Francisco, and Los Angeles, with expansions to Austin, Atlanta, and Miami this year.
- California saw a 50% drop in autonomous vehicle testing in 2024 with 4.5 million miles logged.
- Driverless testing declined by 83%, down to 552,895 miles.
- Fewer companies are testing; Waymo and Cruise were key players, with Cruise halting its tests.
- Only 31 companies hold safety driver permits as of 2024; just 11 are conducting tests.
- The DMV issued one new permit in 2024, down from four in 2022 and two in 2023.
- The industry is consolidating with fewer companies investing in autonomous vehicle development.

title: OpenAI used this subreddit to test AI persuasion
summary:
- OpenAI utilized [r/ChangeMyView](https://www.reddit.com/r/changemyview/) for testing AI's persuasive abilities with its new reasoning model, [o3-mini](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/31/openai-launches-o3-mini-its-latest-reasoning-model/).

summary:

- Despite improvements, foundational AI models will still need extensive GPU resources.
- Mistral's open-source strategy grants free technical support, enhancing its competitive edge.
- The Oxygen GPU sharing program is overbooked, showing high GPU demand in AI.
- AI infrastructure is increasingly seen as strategic, akin to utilities like electricity.
- Sam Altman claims OpenAI has been on the 'wrong side of history' regarding open-source tech.

title: India to Host DeepSeek Models Amid Data Privacy Concerns
summary:
- Ashwini Vaishnaw, India’s IT minister, announced plans to host Chinese AI lab DeepSeek’s large language models on domestic servers.
- This decision addresses data privacy concerns and is significant as it allows Chinese technology in India despite strict data localization policies.
- DeepSeek’s models will be supported by India’s upcoming AI Compute Facility.
- India has banned over 300 Chinese apps since 2020 due to security concerns.
- Vaishnaw emphasized fostering indigenous AI innovation while hosting foreign models.
- The country is investing in hyperscale infrastructure and collaborating with global chip designers to strengthen its AI ecosystem.
- India is also developing a regulatory body for AI safety and funding AI applications in sectors like agriculture and climate change.

- DeepSeek, a Chinese chatbot, gained popularity in the U.S., topping app store charts.
- Hundreds of companies, particularly with government ties, have blocked the service over data security concerns, citing potential data leakage to the Chinese government.
- The Pentagon and the Navy have implemented restrictions against DeepSeek due to its data policies which require sharing user data with Chinese authorities upon request.

sources.title: India to host DeepSeek models on local servers
Hundreds of companies are blocking DeepSeek over China data risks

title: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei is trying to duck a deposition in an OpenAI copyright lawsuit
summary:
- Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei is attempting to avoid a deposition in a copyright lawsuit against OpenAI.
- The Authors Guild has filed a motion to compel testimony from Amodei and his co-founder Benjamin Mann, citing their unique knowledge relevant to the case.
- The lawsuit, representing writers like John Grisham and George R.R. Martin, was filed in September 2023 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.
- Amodei and Mann agreed to seven-hour depositions originally but have since delayed them, hoping to align with another lawsuit's testimony schedule.
- Their lawyers claim Amodei is unavailable for deposition due to a demanding schedule.
- Mann has requested that his deposition be coordinated with other lawsuits and has cited personal reasons for wanting to limit its duration and conditions.

sources.title: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei is trying to duck a deposition in an OpenAI copyright lawsuit

summary:

- O3-mini is optimized for STEM problems, running faster and cheaper than o1-family models.
- It features various reasoning levels for developers and offers competitive pricing against rivals like DeepSeek.
- Available from Friday for ChatGPT premium users, with selective access for developers via OpenAI's API.
- Performance claims indicate higher reliability in technical fields compared to competitors.
- O3-mini outperforms o1-mini in intelligence while maintaining low cost and speed.
- Accessible through API with three reasoning intensity levels for different problem difficulties.
- The model is currently available for ChatGPT Plus, Team, Pro users, with enterprise access coming in a week.

title: CFPB fines fintech Wise, alleging it charged deceptive fees

- Customers were harmed when remittance fees were not refunded in a timely manner.
- Wise has agreed to pay $450,000 in redress to consumers and a civil monetary penalty.
- Wise claims to have cooperated with the CFPB and addressed identified issues promptly.

title: Meta turns to solar — again — in its data center-building boom
summary:

title: Microsoft Establishes Advanced Planning Unit to Study AI Impacts
summary:
- Reid Hoffman discusses the concept of "superagency" related to AI and its potential to enhance human abilities.
- He emphasizes curiosity over fear regarding AI technology and its societal implications.
- Hoffman compares AI to earlier transformative technologies like cars and phones, highlighting both benefits and changes in human agency.
- He encourages engagement with AI to unlock new opportunities and enhance overall capabilities in society.
- Hoffman believes that adapting to AI will require new skills, and he advocates for intentional design to navigate the technological transition successfully.
- Microsoft has established the Advanced Planning Unit (APU) to analyze the societal, health, and work implications of AI.
- The APU will report to CEO Mustafa Suleyman and focus on research, product recommendations, and publications regarding AI's future.
- Current hiring includes economists and psychologists to explore the implications of AI advancements.
- The formation of APU follows a recent creation of a new internal dev-focused organization, CoreAI, to prioritize AI development within Microsoft.
- Microsoft's capital expenditures for Q4 2024 reached a record high of $22.6 billion to support AI efforts, as stated by CEO Satya Nadella.

title: DeepSeek: The Rising AI Chatbot and Market Implications
summary:
- DeepSeek's chatbot app became the top of the Apple App Store charts, prompting discussions about the U.S. AI market.
- Founded in 2023 by High-Flyer Capital Management, DeepSeek developed models in-house despite U.S. hardware export bans.
- Its models, including DeepSeek-V2 and DeepSeek-V3, have outperformed major competitors, leading to significant market reactions.
- The chatbot app went viral, reaching the top of both the [Apple App Store](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/27/deepseek-displaces-chatgpt-as-the-app-stores-top-app/) and [Google Play Store](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/28/deepseek-reaches-no-1-on-us-play-store/).
- DeepSeek is funded by [High-Flyer Capital Management](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/28/who-is-liang-wenfeng-deepseek-founder-comes-from-ai-investing/), a hedge fund focused on AI.
- Its first models were released in November 2023, with [DeepSeek-V2](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/26/deepseeks-new-ai-model-appears-to-be-one-of-the-best-open-challengers-yet/) debuting in Spring 2024, noted for efficiency.
- DeepSeek’s [R1 reasoning model](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/27/deepseek-claims-its-reasoning-model-beats-openais-o1-on-certain-benchmarks/) performs well against OpenAI's offerings.
- Models must adhere to [regulatory benchmarks](https://www.ft.com/content/10975044-f194-4513-857b-e17491d2a9e9) ensuring compliance with socialist values in China.
- Microsoft will integrate DeepSeek models into its [Azure AI Foundry service](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/29/microsoft-brings-a-deepseek-model-to-its-cloud/).
- Market reaction saw an 18% drop in [Nvidia's stock price](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/27/nvidia-drops-600bn-off-its-market-cap-amid-the-rise-of-deepseek/) following DeepSeek's ascent.

title: WhatsApp Disrupts Hacking Campaign Targeting Journalists with Paragon Spyware
summary:
- Nearly 100 journalists and civil society members using WhatsApp were targeted by Israeli spyware from Paragon Solutions.
- The attack, characterized as a “zero-click” breach, indicates users didn't need to interact with malicious content to be compromised.
- WhatsApp has alerted affected users and sent a cease and desist letter to Paragon, exploring legal options while disrupting the attacks in December.
- Paragon’s spyware, Graphite, is comparable to NSO Group’s Pegasus, offering extensive access to infected devices, compromising messages sent through encrypted applications.
- The infection was believed to have been delivered via a malicious PDF file sent to group chat members.
- WhatsApp disrupted a hacking campaign targeting around 90 users, including journalists and civil society members.
- The campaign was linked to Paragon, an Israeli spyware company acquired in December by AE Industrial.
- Malicious PDFs sent via WhatsApp groups were used to compromise victims, and WhatsApp implemented a fix to prevent this.
- The hacking campaign is believed to have occurred in December, with a cease and desist letter sent to Paragon.
- This marks Paragon's first public link to a hacking campaign targeting journalists.
- WhatsApp's actions have been praised by digital rights advocates for holding spyware companies accountable.

title: New technology could make fridges cheaper and more eco-friendly
summary:

- Thermogalvanic cells generate electricity using heat from reversible chemical reactions, representing potential for various applications, including wearable devices.
- Optimizations in chemical use improved cooling power of hydrogalvanic cells by 70%.
- Refrigerators contribute significantly to greenhouse gases, with substantial emissions stemming from their electricity use and gas leakages.

title: Former OpenAI Researcher Raises Alarm About Risks of AI Development
summary:
- Steven Adler, a former safety researcher at [OpenAI](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/openai), expresses concern about the rapid pace of AI development, calling it a "very risky gamble."
- Adler fears the race for artificial general intelligence (AGI) could have catastrophic consequences, highlighting doubts about the future of humanity.
- He notes that no research lab currently has a solution for AI alignment, raising alarms about the industry’s speed compromising safety regulations.
- Steven Adler resigned due to concerns about the rapid pace of AI development, having worked at OpenAI since March 2022.
- He is worried that AGI could exceed human intelligence and warned that the global race to achieve AGI is a 'very risky gamble'.
- Adler emphasized that the urgency may compromise vital safety measures needed for AI alignment with human values.
- Despite assurances from OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Adler hopes for stronger safety regulations within AI labs.
- He mentioned increasing competition, particularly with the launch of DeepSeek by a Chinese startup, and stressed the need for collaboration to mitigate AI risks.

- Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum humorously suggested renaming North America to "América Mexicana" in response to the changes.

title: Tesla Q4 2024 Earnings Report Shows Decline in Deliveries and Mixed Financial Results
summary:

- First annual decline in vehicle deliveries, facing competition from BYD.
- European electric car subsidies are decreasing; vehicle registrations in Europe dropped 24% in October.
- Cybertruck sales have not offset declining demand for older models; autonomous driving software under federal investigation.
- Q4 adjusted profits rose 3% to $2.6 billion, below the estimated $2.9 billion.
- Stock initially fell but rose over 4% after Musk announced unsupervised full self-driving in Austin.
- Quarterly revenue up 2% to $25.7 billion, below the $27.1 billion forecast; gross profit margin at 16.3%.
- Unadjusted profits fell 71% from $7.93 billion year-over-year.
- Tesla sold 1.79 million vehicles in 2024, marking the first drop in over a decade; Q4 set a record with 495,570 sold.
- Musk highlighted a focus on maximizing production and potential for Tesla to become the world's most valuable company.

title: AI creations edited by humans can likely be copyrighted in US, agency says
summary:
- The U.S. Copyright Office stated that AI-generated creations edited by humans can be copyrighted.
- Creations without human edits, like purely AI-generated content, cannot be copyrighted.
- Copyright eligibility is determined on a case-by-case basis; prompts alone do not qualify for copyright.
- A follow-up report from the Copyright Office will address AI making independent artistic choices.

title: DeepSeek exposed internal database containing chat histories and sensitive data
summary:
- Chinese AI company DeepSeek had an exposed back-end database containing sensitive information including user chat histories and API keys.

- The exposed chat logs were primarily in Chinese but could be easily translated.
- It is unclear if other entities accessed the database before it was secured, or how long it had been exposed.
- Misconfiguration is likely due to human error; DeepSeek gained popularity since its launch in December.

title: Czech central bank considers adding bitcoin to reserves
summary:
- The Czech central bank is contemplating the inclusion of bitcoin in its reserves.
- This potential move reflects a growing trend among financial institutions to diversify their asset portfolios with cryptocurrencies.
- The decision could set a precedent in the region regarding central banks' response to digital currencies.

title: Israel launches $61m plan to boost high-tech, deeptech
summary:
- Israel's Ministry of Economy and Industry has launched a nationwide initiative to enhance infrastructure in the high-tech and deeptech sectors.
- The plan consists of 13 projects with a total investment of 220 million shekels (approximately US$61 million).
- Key developments will focus on laboratories, food tech centers, robotic production systems, drone facilities, AI materials labs, and healthcare technologies.
- The initiative aims to support emerging companies and create new job opportunities in these sectors.

title: Apple faces slow growth amid AI delays, China competition
summary:
- Apple's growth has been hindered by delays in AI technology development.
- Increased competition from China is impacting Apple's market performance.
- The company's challenges may affect its long-term profitability and innovation.

sources.title: Apple faces slow growth amid AI delays, China competition

title: Genetic testing firm explores options amid financial issues
summary:
- 23andMe announced on Jan. 28 it is exploring strategic options, including a sale or restructuring.
- Reported an 8% year-over-year decrease in consumer services revenue, falling to US$39.6 million.
- Needs to raise further capital for operations, raising financial stability concerns.
- Market capitalization dropped from US$6 billion to below US$100 million.
- Stock lost 82% of its value in 2024, dropped another 10% in after-hours trading.
- Facing challenges including a rejected proposal to go private and board disagreements.
- Reducing workforce by 40% and exiting its therapeutics division.

sources.title: Genetic testing firm explores options amid financial issues

summary:

- This investment highlights the increasing interest in the edtech industry within the region.

title: Indian enterprise tech startup nets $3.5m seed funding
summary:
- Gallabox, a Chennai-based enterprise tech startup, secured $3.5 million in seed funding.
- Funding led by Seattle’s FUSE Partners, with participation from Prime Venture Partners and Neon Fund.
- Funds will enhance product offerings and support geographic expansion.
- Gallabox, founded in 2021, focuses on no-code conversational commerce for SMEs.
- Serves over 10,000 businesses in 45 countries, with traction in education, real estate, travel, healthcare, and wellness sectors.

summary:

summary:

- The company aims to introduce paid ride-hailing services in the same timeframe.
- This strategy targets broader market segments and enhances EV accessibility.

title: China's AI Competition and Nvidia-TSMC Silicon Photonics Partnership
summary:
- Nvidia has partnered with TSMC to advance silicon photonics technology.
- The announcement was made by CEO Jensen Huang after a meeting with TSMC Chairman C.C. Wei.
- The partnership is in early stages, with expected significant outcomes in the coming years.
- Silicon photonics offers benefits like lower energy consumption, reduced costs, and increased transmission distances.

- The White House emphasized the need for AI to operate on American technology after reports of China's AI advancements.
- China's DeepSeek launched an AI model in November 2024, becoming the most downloaded app on Apple's App Store by January 27, 2025.
- DeepSeek's model reportedly performs as well as OpenAI's ChatGPT-4 but at a significantly lower cost.
- The launch has raised concerns in the US, affecting stock prices of major companies like Nvidia.

sources.title: Nvidia, TSMC partner to advance silicon photonics for AI
Chips don’t lie: Did China’s latest AI just beat the US?

title: World’s largest sovereign wealth fund reports $222b profit
summary:
- Norway’s sovereign wealth fund reported a profit of 2.5 trillion kroner (US$222.4 billion) for 2024.
- This profit surpassed the previous record of 2.22 trillion kroner (US$196.6 billion) from 2023.
- The growth was primarily driven by strong stock market performance, particularly in technology.
- The fund’s total value reached 19.7 trillion kroner (US$1,744 trillion), reflecting a 13% investment return, 45 basis points lower than its benchmark index.
- NBIM CEO Nicolai Tangen highlighted that American technology stocks significantly contributed to the growth.

sources.title: World’s largest sovereign wealth fund reports $222b profit

title: Indian tribunal reinstates US lenders in Byju’s case
summary:
- The National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) has reinstated US lenders Glas Trust Company and Aditya Birla Finance in the creditors’ committee of Byju’s insolvency proceedings.
- The decision removed Pankaj Srivastava, the bankruptcy administrator, who previously excluded Glas Trust due to its involvement in a US case.
- Byju’s, founded in 2015, has faced significant financial struggles and legal issues, with its valuation dropping from US$22 billion to zero since the COVID-19 pandemic.

sources.title: Indian tribunal reinstates US lenders in Byju’s case

summary:
- Trump Media and Technology Group announced the launch of a new financial services brand, Truth.Fi, on Jan. 29.
- Company shares rose over 15% in premarket trading following the announcement.
- The firm plans to diversify cash holdings exceeding US$700 million and has authorized an investment of up to US$250 million through Charles Schwab across various assets.

title: Geotech firm MapmyIndia sees 3% rise on strong Q3 results
summary:
- Shares of MapmyIndia increased nearly 3% on Jan. 29, closing at 1,654 rupees (US$19.10).
- Q3 2025 consolidated net profit rose 4% YoY to 32.32 crore rupees (US$3.73 million).
- EBITDA grew 15.7% to 41.7 crore rupees (US$4.82 million) but EBITDA margin declined to 36.4%.
- Revenue from operations increased by 24% to 114.54 crore rupees (US$13.23 million).
- Operating expenses rose 32% to 79.40 crore rupees (US$9.17 million).
- MapmyIndia acquired a 9.37% stake in AI startup SimDaaS Autonomy for 3 crore rupees (US$346,521).
- The company partnered with KOGO AI to introduce India’s first universal voice assistant for the automotive industry.
- MapmyIndia targets to surpass 1,000 crore rupees (US$115.51 million) in revenue by FY27-FY28 with a CAGR of 35-40%.

sources.title: Geotech firm MapmyIndia sees 3% rise on strong Q3 results

title: AI agent platform AI16z rebrands as ElizaOS
summary:
- AI platform AI16z has rebranded to ElizaOS due to trademark issues with the name's similarity to a16z.
- Founder Shaw Walters announced the change on social media for a more professional identity.
- ElizaOS's cryptocurrency token will retain the ai16z ticker temporarily, with future changes decided by community vote via DAO.

title: Funding Success for ElevenLabs and Finout
summary:
- ElevenLabs raised a Series C funding of $250 million, achieving a valuation of $3 billion to $3.3 billion.
- The funding round is led by ICONIQ Growth, with previous investors like Andreessen Horowitz.
- ElevenLabs specializes in AI-driven synthetic voice technology, including voice cloning and dubbing tools.
- Investors are interested due to significant growth in ElevenLabs' technology and applications.
- Founded in 2022 by Mati Staniszewski and Piotr Dabkowski to improve dubbing quality in media.
- Technology includes text-to-speech, voice cloning, and creating new voices for various industries.
- Finout raised $40 million in a Series C funding round, bringing total funding to $80 million.
- The funding will enhance Finout's cloud cost management platform.

sources.title: ElevenLabs has raised a new round at $3B+ valuation led by ICONIQ Growth, sources say

title: Israeli AI firm UVeye raises $191m for global vehicle scans
summary:
- UVeye, an Israeli AI company, raised US$191 million for vehicle inspection technology.
- Funding included a US$41 million equity investment led by Woven Capital, Toyota's growth fund.
- Additionally, US$150 million was raised through debt financing via Trinity Capital.
- Founded in 2016, UVeye provides rapid, data-driven vehicle inspections used by dealerships, fleets, and auction sites.

title: ASML Sees $7.4 Billion in Q4 Bookings Amid AI Demand and Growth Concerns
summary:
- ASML will report Q4 earnings on January 31.
- Concerns arise over growth outlook for 2025 due to DeepSeek's AI model requiring less computing power.
- Uncertainty exists regarding potential US export restrictions on ASML's older DUV products to China.
- ASML projects 2025 sales of €30-35 billion driven by AI chip demand, but investors await confirmation through bookings.
- ASML reported €7.09 billion (US$7.4 billion) in Q4 2024 bookings, exceeding expectations of €3.53 billion (US$3.68 billion).
- Increased demand attributed to AI growth, despite concerns over China's AI advancements.
- ASML's market value fell by €19 billion (US$19.80 billion) over DeepSeek's competitive AI claims.
- US export restrictions continue to limit ASML's advanced lithography sales to China.
- AI infrastructure investments from Meta, OpenAI, SoftBank, and Oracle may benefit ASML.
- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) plans up to US$42 billion in spending for 2025, indicating strong demand.

sources.title: ASML faces growth concerns amid DeepSeek, Trump export risks
AI demand boosts ASML’s Q4 bookings to $7.4b

title: SoftBank Plans Up to $25B Investment in OpenAI Amid Microsoft's $80B AI Cloud Push
summary:
- Microsoft will announce its quarterly revenue forecast on Jan. 29, emphasizing its $80 billion AI investments' effect on Azure cloud growth.
- Azure is projected to grow by 31.8% in Q2, recovering from two quarters of slower growth.
- Microsoft's growth rebound is linked to its partnership with OpenAI, which dominates consumer and developer traffic on Azure.
- Microsoft's intelligent cloud segment is expected to grow by 19.7%, with overall revenue growth at 10.9% and net profit growth at 6.3%.
- SoftBank is in talks to invest up to $25 billion in OpenAI, potentially becoming its largest supporter.
- The investment aligns with SoftBank's $40 billion commitment to AI initiatives, including a $100 billion Stargate project.
- OpenAI has accused DeepSeek of violating service terms by using proprietary models to train its R1 model.
- This investment comes amid significant market losses for Nvidia due to costly AI hardware concerns.

sources.title: Microsoft focus on cloud growth with $80b AI investment
SoftBank in talks to invest as much as $25B in OpenAI, report says

title: Trump Campaign Manager Joins Coinbase Advisory Council
summary:
- Coinbase Global Inc. has announced new members for its global advisory council.
- Chris LaCivita, co-manager of Trump’s presidential campaign, is one of the new members.
- Other appointees include former Federal Reserve Bank of New York president William Dudley, former Senator Kyrsten Sinema, and Luis Alberto Moreno.
- The appointments aim to help Coinbase expand into payments and tokenized assets.
- Announcement date: January 29.

sources.title: Trump Campaign Manager Joins Coinbase Advisory Council
